objectDesc.p: Typed letter with handwritten signature from Edward Jones to Eartha M. M. White on 4/11/1967 regarding an effort to find and document black communities history in and contribution to Florida; letter accompanied by envelope.

div.p:
I am soliciting your help in spreading an idea concerning the Negro of every
community in Florida.

The problem is, "What can we do to acquaint ourselves with the past and
present history of our foreparents and present generation?" You might call
this effort research. Personally, I think the time is far pass for us to
rely on other groups to realize what they have found out about the NegorNegro, and
hold back pertinent information concerning us. In every county in this state,
Negroes have made a contribution as a slave or free "folks." All that is
needed is for us to organize a procedure to dig up information, sort, sift,
and document.

To attack the overall problem of reserachresearch, I suggest that every high school
or college within a county form groups in order to find information. Asking
older citizens about yesteryears may bring back memories to them, which will
be a help to them as well as giving you a sense of responsibility. Newspapers
and magazines give a good bit of past and present history. Clippings from
all sources, although they are happening now, will be history in years to
come.

I do hope you will find favor in the above suggestions, whereby young men
and women will begin preparing, no matter what field of life they are in
terested in.
div.closer:
Yours truly,
Edward Jones
Edward Jones
Department of Painting and Decorating
EJ:as
P. S. I command you to read Carpetbag Rule in Florida, by John Wallace,
(Negro, 1888). You will have a better idea of the part Negro played in Florida.
